Yes, the Inca civilization used a technique called Ashlar masonry to create their intricate stone structures without using mortar. Ashlar masonry consists of carefully fitting together large stone blocks that interlock with each other, creating a solid wall structure. This technique was used to create not only impressive buildings like the fortress of Sacsayhuaman in Cusco, but also the famous buildings of Machu Picchu.

The Inca stonemasons carefully measured, cut and polished each stone block to fit together perfectly with the surrounding blocks. They used simple tools like chisels, hammers, and bronze and stone handheld drills for carving and shaping the stones. To move the stones, the Inca civilization used wooden rollers to transport the stones from the quarry to the building site.

Ashlar masonry was a time-consuming process, but it allowed the Inca stonemasons to create structures that remain standing today and are admired for their beauty and durability. This technique was passed down from generation to generation, and even after the arrival of the Spanish conquistadors, the Inca people continued to use Ashlar masonry in their constructions.
